member.name: T:Microsoft.Research.CommunityTechnologies.AppLib.ColorPicker
member.summary: Represents a user control that allows the user to pick a color.
member.remarks:
The user control consists of a panel that displays the current color and a button that opens the standard ColorDialog for editing the color.
Use the property to set the initial color after the user control is created. If you are just displaying the color and don't want the user to edit it, set to false to hide the button. A event is fired when the user edits the color. Read the property to get the edited color.

member.summary: Processes Windows messages.

member.summary: Asserts if the object is in an invalid state. Debug-only.

members.member: Indicates whether click-through is used.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Research.CommunityTechnologies.AppLib.ToolStripPlus.ClickThrough
member.summary: Gets or sets a flag indicating whether click-through is used.
member.value: true if clicking a control in the ToolStrip activates the ToolStrip AND clicks the clicked control. The default is true.
member.remarks:
In a standard ToolStrip, if window B is active when a control in window A's ToolStrip is clicked, the click activates window A but doesn't click the control. A second click on the control is then required. When this property is true, only a single click is required to both activate the ToolStrip and click the control.
The code to accomplish this is borrowed from Rick Brewster:
http://blogs.msdn.com/rickbrew/archive/2006/01/09/511003.aspx

member.summary: Enables or disables all descendent tool strip menu items of a specified parent tool strip menu item.
member.param: true to enable the items, false to disable them.
Parent tool strip menu item whose descendent tool strip menu items should be enabled or disabled.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.CommunityTechnologies.AppLib.MenuUtil.GetMenuPath(System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem[])
member.summary: Gets a string describing the path to a tool strip menu item.
member.param: Sequence of one or more menu items. Each item must be a child of the previous item. Sample: mniFile, mniFileNew, mniFileNewDocument.
member.returns: A string describing the path to the last menu item in . Sample: "File, New, Document".
member.remarks:
Use this method to obtain a displayable path to a menu item in a robust manner. Instead of hardcoding the string "File, New, Document" in a user message, for example, pass the sequence of menu item to this method and use the returned string in the message. Then if the text of any of the menu items is changed, the message will change automatically. Also, if one of the menu items is moved or deleted, an exception is thrown to alert the programmer to the problem.
This can be used only in .NET 2.0 and later applications. You must define a "NET20" compiler constant.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Research.CommunityTechnologies.AppLib.ComboBoxPlus
member.summary: Represents a ComboBox with additional features.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.CommunityTechnologies.AppLib.ComboBoxPlus.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the ComboBoxPlus class.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.CommunityTechnologies.AppLib.ComboBoxPlus.PopulateWithEnumValues(System.Type,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Populates the ComboBox with all values in an enumeration.
member.param: Enumeration to populate the ComboBox with.

If true, spaces are inserted between each word in the enum values, and the values are sorted alphabetically. The value "DaysActiveInNewsgroup" gets displayed as "Days active in newsgroup", for example. If false, the values are displayed as is ("DaysActiveInNewsgroup", for example), and no sorting is done.
member.remarks: This method populates a ListControl with all values in an enumeration. The user sees the string version of each value in the list. The property returns the selected value in the enumeration.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.CommunityTechnologies.AppLib.ComboBoxPlus.PopulateWithObjectsAndText(System.Object[])
member.summary: Populates the ComboBox with arbitrary objects and associated text.
member.param: One or more object/text pairs. The text is what gets displayed in the ComboBox. The associated object, which can be of any type, is hidden from the user but can be retrieved using the property.
member.remarks: When you populate the ComboBox with this method, you can set and get the selected object with the property.
member.example:
This example populates a combo box with three items. The user sees "None", "10%", and "20%" in the list. The property returns either 0, 0.1, or 0.2, depending on which item the user has selected.
oComboBox.PopulateWithObjectsAndText(0, "None", 0.1, "10%", 0.2, "20%");

member.name: T:Microsoft.NodeXL.ApplicationUtil.LayoutManagerForMenu
member.summary: Helper class for managing graph layouts.
member.remarks:
This class is meant for use in applications that allow the user to select a graph layout via a parent "Layout" menu that has one child menu item per available layout. It provides methods for populating the menu and for creating a layout of the selected type.
Call during application initialization. When the user selects one of the menu items added by this method, the event fires. In the event handler, call to create a layout of the selected type.

member.name: T:Microsoft.NodeXL.ApplicationUtil.LayoutManager
member.summary: Helper class for managing graph layouts.
member.remarks:
This class defines a set of available layouts. (A layout is a class that implements . It provides a property for keeping track of the layout type currently in use, a event that is raised when the layout is changed, and a method for creating a layout of the current type.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Research.CommunityTechnologies.AppLib.FormSettings
member.summary: Saves a form's window state and rectangle in the user's settings.
member.remarks:
This can be used as a base class for storing user settings in a Windows Forms application. This class automatically saves the window state, location, and optionally size (if the form is resizable) of a specified form when the form closes, and restores them when the form is loaded.
Derive a class from this one, add any form-specific user setting properties to the derived class, instantiate the dervied class in the form's constructor, and save the instantiated object in a member field.
It is not necessary to call when the form is closing. This class does that automatically.
This is for .NET 2.0 and later applications only.

members.member: Name of the settings key for the FormWindowState property.
Name of the settings key for the FormSize property.
Name of the settings key for the FormLocation property.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.CommunityTechnologies.AppLib.FormPlus.OnFirstActivated
member.summary: Gets called the first time the form is activated.
member.remarks:
Override this method to perform time-consuming initialization tasks without preventing the form from appearing.
If a form executes time-consuming code in its constructor (such as getting data from a network server), the form doesn't appear until the code has completed, leaving the user with no idea what's going on. Waiting until the form is first activated to run lengthy code solves this, because the form is visible at that point.
Do not put time-consuming code in an OnLoad() handler, because the form isn't visible when OnLoad() runs.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.CommunityTechnologies.AppLib.FormPlus.EnsureVisibleOnVisibleChanged(System.Object,System.EventArgs)
member.summary: VisibleChanged handler that ensures that the form is not off the screen when it's made visible.
member.remarks: If the form has a FormBorderStyle of SizableToolWindow, you should set the form's VisibleChanged handler to this method. This is to work around an apparent bug in WinForms: If FormBorderStyle is SizableToolWindow, you can drag the window below the bottom of the screen, where it becomes invisible and impossible to retrieve.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SocialNetworkLib.EmailNetworkAnalyzer
member.summary: Analyzes a user's email social network.
member.remarks: Use one of the overloads to synchronously analyze a user's email social network, or use to do it asynchronously.

members.member: The connection string to use for Windows Desktop Search.
Command timeout for the OleDbCommand object, in seconds.
Base query that returns all email items.
Character used to separate two participants in the aggregated dictionary key.
Number of records to process before checking whether a cancellation of an asynchronous analysis has been requested.
Name of the method used to analyze email. Gets used in error messages.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SocialNetworkLib.EmailNetworkAnalyzer.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SocialNetworkLib.EmailNetworkAnalyzer.AnalyzeEmailNetwork
member.overloads: Synchronously analyzes a user's email social network.
member.summary: Synchronously analyzes a user's entire email social network.
member.returns: An array of zero or more objects, one for each pair of participants in the user's email social network. The return value is never null.
member.remarks:
This method uses the Windows Desktop Search index to analyze the user's email. For each email item in the index, a tie strength of 1 is assigned to each From-To and From-Cc participant pair. For example, if an email item has these fields:
From: John To: Mary, Bob Cc: Sarah
then the following participant pairs are created:
John, Mary, 1 John, Bob, 1 John, Sarah, 1
The process is repeated for every email item. If a second email item has these fields, for example:
From: John To: Sarah
then the following participant pair is created:
John, Sarah, 1
The process is repeated for every email item and the results are aggregated. For the two emails in this example, the aggregated results look like this:
John, Mary, 1 John, Bob, 1 John, Sarah, 2
The aggregated set of objects is returned.
If a connection to the Windows Desktop Search index can't be made, a is thrown. If a connection is made but the query fails, an is thrown.

member.summary: Synchronously analyzes the part of a user's email social network that satisfies specified criteria.
member.param: An array of objects, one for each participant to filter on, or null to not filter on participants. For each element in the array, must be specified, but can be .
If specified, only emails sent on or after the specified time are included in the aggregated results. Use null to specify "no start time."
If specified, only emails sent on or before the specified time are included in the aggregated results. Use null to specify "no end time."
Body text to filter on, or null to not filter on body text. Can't be an empty string. If specified, only emails that include the specified body text are included in the aggregated results.

Email folder to filter on, or null to not filter on the email folder. Can't be an empty string. If specified, only emails in the specified folder are included in the aggregated results. Sample: "Inbox".
If specified, only emails that have a size greater than or equal to the specified value are included in the aggregated results.
If specified, only emails that have a size less than or equal to the specified value are included in the aggregated results.
If not null, specifies how attachments are used to determine which emails are included in the aggregated results. Use null to specify "don't care."
If specified, only emails that have or don't have a Cc line are included in the aggregated results. Use null to specify "don't care."
If specified, only emails that have or don't have a Bcc line are included in the aggregated results. Use null to specify "don't care."

If specified, only emails that are or are not replies from are included in the aggregated results. Use null to specify "don't care."
[IMPORTANT NOTE: As of April 2008, the System.Message.IsFwdOrReply message property needed to implement this is always null. Specifying true or false for this parameter will always return an empty array. The parameter is retained in case the missing property is fixed in a future version of Windows Desktop Search.]
If true, a tie strength of one is assigned to the sender and each participant on the Cc line. (A tie strength of one is always assigned to the sender and each participant on the To line.)
If true, a tie strength of one is assigned to the sender and each participant on the Bcc line. (A tie strength of one is always assigned to the sender and each participant on the To line.)
member.returns: An array of zero or more objects, one for each pair of participants in the user's email social network that satisfy the specified criteria. The return value is never null.
member.remarks: This overload does the same thing as the overload, but only those emails that match the specified criteria are aggregated.

When the analysis cancels, the event fires. The property will be true.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Research.CommunityTechnologies.AppLib.SaveImageFileDialog
member.summary: Represents a dialog box for saving an image file.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Research.CommunityTechnologies.AppLib.SaveFileDialog2
member.summary: Represents a smart SaveFileDialog that knows how to get a file name from the user and save an object to the file. Abstract.
member.remarks:
This is an abstract base class. Each class derived from this one is responsible for saving one type of object, such as an image or an XML document.
A derived class must implement GetDialogTitle(), GetFilter(), and SaveObject(). It should also implement a public method called ShowDialogAndSaveXXX(), where XXX is Image or XML, for example. ShowDialogAndSaveXXX() should call ShowDialogAndSaveObject() in this base class to do most of the work.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.CommunityTechnologies.AppLib.SaveFileDialog2.#ctor(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the SaveFileDialog2 class.
member.param: Initial directory the dialog will display. Use an empty string to let the dialog select an initial directory.
Initial file name. Can be a complete path, a path without an extension, a file name, or a file name without an extension.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.CommunityTechnologies.AppLib.SaveFileDialog2.ShowDialogAndSaveObject(System.Object)
member.summary: Shows the file save dialog and saves the object to the selected file.
member.returns: DialogResult. DialogResult.OK if the user selected a file name and the object was successfully saved.
member.remarks: This method allows the user to select a file name and format. It then saves the object in the selected format. The virtual method SaveObject() implemented in the derived class does the actual saving. All other details are handled by this base-class method.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.CommunityTechnologies.AppLib.SaveFileDialog2.GetNameOfFileToSave
member.summary: Returns the full name of the file to save.
member.returns: String. Full name of the file to save, including the extension.
member.remarks:
This method works around an odd behavior in SaveFileDialog. If the user enters a file name that contains a period, SaveFileDialog does not add an extension to the file name returned by the FileName property. If the user enters "A.B" into the file name text box and the selected filter is "JPEG (*.jpg)", for example, the FileName property returns "A.B" instead of "A.B.jpg". It probably assumes that the user wants an extension of ".B", so it doesn't add an extension of its own.
This method adds the extension if it's missing.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.CommunityTechnologies.AppLib.SaveFileDialog2.GetDialogTitle(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the title to use for the dialog.
member.returns: Title to use for the dialog. Sample: "Save As Image".
member.remarks: Derived classes must implement this virtual method.

member.summary: Returns the filter to use for the dialog.
member.returns: Filter to use for the dialog.
member.remarks: Derived classes must implement this virtual method.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Research.CommunityTechnologies.AppLib.OpenFileDialog2
member.summary: Represents a smart OpenFileDialog that knows how to get a file name from the user and open an object from the file. Abstract.
member.remarks:
This is an abstract base class. Each class derived from this one is responsible for opening one type of file and creating an object from the file contents. A file type might be an image or an XML document, for example.
A derived class must implement GetDialogTitle(), GetFilter(), and OpenObject(). It should also implement a public method called ShowDialogAndOpenXXX(), where XXX is Image or XML, for example. ShowDialogAndOpenXXX() should call ShowDialogAndOpenObject() in this base class to do most of the work.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.CommunityTechnologies.AppLib.OpenFileDialog2.#ctor(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the OpenFileDialog2 class.
member.param: Initial directory the dialog will display. Use an empty string to let the dialog select an initial directory.
Initial file name. Can be a complete path, a path without an extension, a file name, or a file name without an extension.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.CommunityTechnologies.AppLib.OpenFileDialog2.ShowDialogAndOpenObject(System.Object@)
member.summary: Opens a file and creates an object from the file contents.
member.param: Where the object created from the file contents will be stored.
member.returns: DialogResult.OK if the user selected a file name and the file was successfully opened.
member.remarks: This method allows the user to select a file name. It then opens the file and creates an object from the file contents. The virtual method OpenObject() implemented in the derived class does the actual opening. All other details are handled by this base-class method.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.CommunityTechnologies.AppLib.OpenFileDialog2.GetDialogTitle
member.summary: Returns the title to use for the dialog.
member.returns: Title to use for the dialog. Sample: "Open XML".
member.remarks: Derived classes must implement this virtual method.

member.summary: Returns the filter to use for the dialog.
member.returns: Filter to use for the dialog.
member.remarks: Derived classes must implement this virtual method.

member.summary: Create an object from a file.
member.param: Where the new object gets stored.
member.remarks: Derived classes must implement this virtual method. Any exceptions thrown by the derived method are caught and handled by this base class.

member.summary: Gets called when an error occurs while opening a file.

When the analysis completes, the event fires. The property will return a object.
To cancel the analysis, call .

When the analysis cancels, the event fires. The property will be true.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Research.CommunityTechnologies.AppLib.ListViewPlus
member.summary: Represents a ListView with additional features.
member.remarks:
This ListView-derived object supports sorting by a column that contains data of an arbitrary type. To enable sorting, populate the collection, then call the method. You can then call the method to sort by a specified column. Sorting also occurs automatically when the user clicks a column header.
By default, right-clicking an item in the ListView shows a context menu with a set of standard menu items supported by this base class. If the derived class needs a custom context menu, it should set to false and override OnMouseUp(). The derived OnMouseUp() should create and show a custom context menu, then call the base-class method. If the custom context menu should contain the standard menu items in addition to the custom items, should be called to add those items to the menu.
Leave the property set to its default value of SortOrder.None.

member.summary: Gets the index of the column for which a copy command should be included in context menus.
